item.title: Enable SSH key based authentication on Synology NAS
item.description: Introduction In this post I’d like to describe how I solved a little issue I had with my Synology NAS. Synology NAS run a Linux based system, AFAIK it’s IIRC which is a customized Debian fork. To copy files from/to NAS I also use SFTP, SCP or SSHFS, both based on OpenSSH. To eliminate the need to enter my password and to improve security I always prefer to use SSH key based authentication in combination with an SSH agent.

item.title: Learning Pytest - part 1
item.description: Pytest Intro Not even a year ago I started on a position, where I also work on software and system testing. There is a lot to comprehend and a lot to learn. Besides specific topic and tasks I’d like to also extend my general knowledge. This is why I started to read and implement the examples/exercises from the book Python Testing with pytest written by Brian Okken. This blog post will probably evolve and I’d like to have here my notes taken from this book.

item.title: Git Commands - My Cheatsheet
item.description: Git Commands - My Cheatsheet I am using git almost every time a I work on a computer. Somehow I find the CLI interface the quickest, especially in combination with aliases provided by oh-my-zsh git plugin. This blog post provides however full commands, they are here mainly for my reference as I don’t use very often majority of them. Clone Clone a content of a repository into a directory (Note, if the directory does not exist yet, it will be automatically created) git clone URL bar Remotes List all remotes of the branch git remote -v Add a new remote called myremote git remote add myremote URL git fetch myremote Branches Create a new branch which is a copy of the current one git checkout -b <name-of-new-branch> if a remote ‘myremote’ has a special branch, use –track to configure sync with the this remote branch git checkout -b <name-of-new-branch> -- track myremote/<remote-branch> Switch to another existing branch git checkout <name-of-another-branch> Switch to another branch, which has not been yet used locally git fetch git checkout -b <branch-name> <remote>/<branch-name> # or shorthand: git checkout -t <remote>/<branch-name> Staging Stage a file git add <file-name> Stage all files in the current directory recursively git add .

item.title: Prevent Grep From Showing Up
item.description: Prevent grep from showing up in ‘ps’ output You don’t want the grep process itself to show up in the list of process (ps) when filtering with the grep. In the example below, the second line should not appear. $ ps -few | grep nvim vagrant 12337 11456 0 14:55 pts/6 00:00:00 nvim vagrant 12340 4979 0 14:55 pts/3 00:00:00 grep --color=auto nvim How to to achieve it? You can use ‘-v’ or ‘–invert-match’ switch of grep as follows:

item.title: Learning Go
item.description: Learning Go - Notes Notes which I took during my learning. It’d be great if they would also help you. Go is statically written (type of every variable must be defined), pass by value (whenever you pass an argument into a function, Go creates a copy of each argument, and these copies are used inside of the function) programming language. Go workspace and basics MUST READ DOCUMENT Syntax Variable declaration if you define a variable within the if statement(condition) it is valid only there.

item.title: Notes
item.description: This section shows you my various notes about technical topics. I started to take notes some time ago when I could not memorize the stuff. In my case, it really helps and provides me a good reference. I how you find it usefull too. Please note, that this is a evolving page. Notes here may not be well structured and/or formulated. GNU/Linux administration commands and concepts To cancel shutdown shutdown -ci or pkill shutdown

item.title: Welcome
item.description: This is a personal page of Frantisek Janus. I’m IT professional living in Zürich area. The content of this page is focused on technical topics, mainly from my work or about topics which interests me. You can find 2 main content sections here: 1. Notes - intended to be one long document with my quick notes. 2. Blog - posts where I would like to go a little deeper or to be more verbose.
